questions.text: Which of the following is the most common benign tumor of the liver?
questions.solution:
Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign tumor of the liver.

It appears as a red-blue, soft nodule, usually < 2 cm in diameter. It may be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for a metastatic tumor.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of abdominal pain. She has been taking oral contraceptives for the past 7 years. CECT reveals an isodense lesion in the liver with homogenous enhancement in the arterial phase and washout in the portal venous phase. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It can be associated with MODY-3
Serum amyloid A may be upregulated
Î²-catenin-activated adenoma has no risk of malignant transformation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatic adenoma. β-catenin-activated adenomas have a high risk of malignant transformation.

Hepatic adenomas are benign tumors of hepatocytes. Spontaneous rupture of the hepatic adenoma may cause intraabdominal bleeding, which is a surgical emergency.

Hepatic adenomas are classified into 3 subtypes:

  • HNF1-α-inactivated adenomas -
    • No risk of malignant transformation
    • Often associated with oral contraceptive pill use (OCP) and MODY-3
  • β-catenin-activated adenoma -
    • High risk of malignant transformation
    • Associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCP) and anabolic steroids usage
  • Inflammatory adenomas -
    • Associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
    • Upregulation of C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A 
    • 10% may have concomitant β-catenin activating mutations
    • Moderate risk of malignant transformation

questions.text: Patients with cirrhosis of the liver are at a higher risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
Dysplastic nodules are associated with liver cirrhosis.

High grade dysplastic nodules may eventually develop into hepatocellular carcinoma in viral hepatitis and alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought with abdominal swelling. On examination, a mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant.  Laboratory evaluation shows serum alpha-fetoprotein level of 1,50,000 ng/mL. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level are suggestive of hepatoblastoma.

Hepatoblastoma is the most common malignant liver tumor of early childhood, usually < 3 years. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the most important clinical marker for hepatoblastoma. It remains the key clinical marker of malignant change, response to the treatment, and relapse.

questions.text: Patients with all of the following are at a higher risk of developing hepatoblastoma except:

choices.text: A 6-year-old child diagnosed with new-onset hypertension
A premature infant with low birth weight
A 5-year-old child diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
A 9-year-old child with a family history of familial adenatomatous polyposis

questions.solution:
Hypertension is not a risk factor for hepatoblastoma.

Risk factors for hepatoblastoma include:

  • Prematurity and low birth weight (LBW)
  • Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

questions.text: Which of the following parameters indicates a good prognosis in hepatoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Pure fetal histology hepatoblastoma is associated with a very good prognosis. They may be cured by surgical resection without adjuvant chemotherapy.

Prognostic factors in hepatoblastoma include:

Low tumor stage

Pure fetal histology

High tumor stage

Low AFP levels

Small cell undifferentiated histology

Rhabdoid features

Vascular invasion

Prematurity and low-birth weight (LBW) are associated with hepatoblastoma but do not affect its outcome.

questions.text: Which one of the following syndromes is associated with a higher incidence of hepatoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrome is associated with hepatoblastoma.

Activation of WNT signaling plays a major role in hepatoblastomas. This occurs by a variety of mechanisms including mutations in APC gene. Hence, patients with FAP syndromes frequently develop hepatoblastomas.

The following syndromes are associated with hepatocellular carcinoma:

  • Hereditary tyrosinemia
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin defeciency
  • Familial hemochromatosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma is chronic hepatitis B virus infection. More than 85% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma occur in countries with high rates of chronic hepatitis B virus infection.

Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma are:

  • Hepatitis B virus
  • Hepatitis C virus 
  • Alcohol
  • Aflatoxin
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Tyrosinemia
  • Smoking

Activation of β-catenin and inactivation of p53 are the two most common early mutational events seen in hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the precursor lesions for hepatocellular carcinoma?
  1. Hepatocellular adenoma
  2. Small cell change
  3. Nodular regenerative hyperplasia
  4. Large cell change
  5. Focal nodular hyperplasia
questions.solution:
Focal nodular hyperplasia and nodular regenerative hyperplasia are not precursors for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

The precursors of HCC inlcude:

  • Hepatocellular adenoma - especially those with β-catenin-activating mutations
  • Small cell and large cell change - cellular dysplasias
  • Dysplastic nodules - low-grade and high-grade

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with chronic abdominal discomfort. Imaging reveals a solitary well-encapsulated hepatic mass with a central fibrous scar and stellate calcification. Further investigations reveal elevated neurotensin levels and negative hepatitis B serology. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Histology reveals oncocytic hepatocytes separated by collagen bundles
It is associated with a relatively good prognosis
Majority of these tumors are resectable
It is associated with liver cirrhosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fibrolamellar carcinoma. It is usually not associated with liver cirrhosis.

Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive and rare variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It usually occurs < 35 years of age. There is no gender predilection and no identifiable predisposing conditions. It has a good prognosis compared to the classical HCC. Majority (50-75%) of these tumors are resectable.

It usually presents as a single large, hard scirrhous tumor with fibrous bands coursing through it. Microscopically, it is composed of oncocytes growing in nests or cords separated by parallel lamellae of dense collagen bundles.

The histological section of fibrolamellar carcinoma is given below. It shows malignant-appearing, oncocytic hepatocytes separated by dense bundles of collagen.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not associated with the development of hepatic angiosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with exposure to arsenic, thorotrast and vinyl chloride. 

Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm. There is equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast and liver.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common tumor of the liver?
questions.solution:
The most common tumors of the liver are metastatic tumors.

The common primary sources of liver metastasis are:

  • Colon carcinoma
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient with anorexia and weight loss is found to have non-tender hepatomegaly on physical examination. CT scan of the abdomen shows multiple nodules in the liver and investigations reveal elevated ALP and AST levels, with no elevations in AFP. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a metastatic liver tumor.

Metastases are the most common malignant neoplasms of the liver. The most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas, although any cancer at any site of the body may spread to the liver.

Patients with metastases typically have multiple nodules replacing the normal liver parenchyma. There may be no clinical or laboratory evidence of hepatic insufficiency. Often, the only telltale sign of secondaries in the liver will be hepatomegaly.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Typhoid carriers are not at risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma. 

Cholangiocarcinoma is the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after hepatocellular carcinoma. It is a malignancy of the biliary tree, arising from bile ducts within and outside of the liver.

The risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma include the following:

  • Infestation by liver flukes (particularly Opisthorchis and Clonorchis )
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis, and other chronic inflammatory diseases of the large bile ducts
  • Chronic hepatitis B and C infections
  • Cirrhosis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Diabetes mellitus, obesity, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
  • Alcohol and tobacco
  • Precursor lesions -
    • Biliary intraepithelial neoplasias
    • Mucinous cystic neoplasms
    • Intraductal papillary biliary neoplasia

questions.text: What does Klatskin tumor refer to?
questions.solution:
Klatskin tumors are extrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas located in the perihilar region.

These tumors are located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts. Distal tumors arise in the common bile duct posterior to the duodenum. Regardless of the site, the prognosis is poor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding gallbladder carcinoma?

choices.text: Gallstones are the most important risk factor
Her2 overexpression is seen in about 2/3 of the cases
It usually has a good prognosis

questions.solution:
Gallbladder carcinoma carries a poor prognosis because it is typically detected late due to non-specific symptoms.

Carcinoma of the gallbladder is the most common malignancy of the extrahepatic biliary tract. Most carcinomas of the gall bladder are adenocarcinomas.

Gallbladder cancer is at least twice as common in women than in men. The most important risk factor for gallbladder cancer (besides gender and ethnicity) is gallstones, which are present in 95% of cases. Her-2/neu is overexpressed in around 2/3 of the cases, and therefore, they can be targeted for therapy.
